comments:
(my apologies if core was the incorrect component - I was unsure)

I'm running eclipse-SDK-3.0M7-win32 on Windows XP. I used the New Project 
wizard to create a 'Plug-in Development > Plug-in Project' for me (project 
name 123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345 - standard alpha names 
produce the same results). I used all defaults in the wizard, except for the 
project settings - these I changed to 'Create a simple project'. [to add 
simple function to the plug-in, I extended the help system to add a help 
navigation entry - however, without any plug-in functionality, I still get the 
same errors in the .log file].

Given this plug-in in my workspace, with its name/id greater than 44 
characters in length, a runtime workbench will not launch the plug-in. The 
same plug-in *does* get launched if I put it in my plugins/ directory and 
launch the workbench from scratch.

The contents of my runtime-workspace .log file:

Looks like the 255 character filename limit is being hit on Windows. The choice
of temp location for the manifest files is not helping here.  I suspect bundle
manifest files could instead use arbitrary integer filenames to avoid problems
caused by long bundle names.

This problem already happened before (see bug #47907) and we already shortened 
the path.
However we need to have the name in the manifest filename so we can reuse 
manifest as much as possible and avoid leaving stale files.
Why not just the bundle id as the name of the manifest file? 1.MF, 2.MF etc.

As Pascal said, we want to minimize the chances of having to regenerate the
plugin manifest. Being able to easily map a plugin identifier to a bundle
manifest location helps a lot in that sense. Also,  bundle ids are opaque (not
human-friendly) and dynamic (the generated manifests are reusable even if we
discard all the framework related files).

Wassim, do you really need to take the whole workspace location to compute a
unique configuration location when self-hosting? The result is a configuration
location that is at least twice as long as the workspacece location. That takes
a big part of our allowance for file paths. Wouldn't it be possible to use the
launch configuration name instead? That would still ensures unicity (since
multiple launch configs with the same name are not allowed). Correct me if I am
wrong, but it seems even better, since currently two different launch configs
can end up having the same configuration area (if their workspace locations are
the same).

I took Rafael's suggestion in comment #5 and shortened the name of the config 
area.  this is effective tommorrow's I-build.

Moving back to Equinox...

What are we thinking we'll do on this one?  Changing the manifest file names to 
numerics (e.g., 1.MF, ...) has the outlined drawbacks, at least in the normal 
case.  In the PDE rutime workspace case it might be ok if we are assuming a) 
that speed is not quite as important and b) that things are changing anyway.  
Not sure I believe these in the case of large targets (eg.., WSAD).

In fact, we should be seeking ways of reusing already generated manifests from 
the target platform (if they are generated).

So, my stake in the ground is that we do nothing further here.

Apologies - I should have verified this long ago. I've now verified it with
eclipse-SDK-3.1M4-win32 - works fine now (I tried with a project id of just over
90 characters).
